text: okay and again welcome to the webcast today what's new with amazon elastic transcoder our presenter today is david
sayeth principal product manager at aws david you have the floor
thank you very much bowen hi everyone my name is david syed i'm the uh uh product manager for uh amazon scholastic
transcoder um which is a service that we launched back at the end of january and
we've been steadily releasing uh new functionality so the main aim of um the
webcast today is to go over the new features that we launched a couple of
weeks ago we have other webcasts that are archived and available
through the amazon elastic transcoder website that contain information about the features that we released at launch
as well as the feature update that we made in the middle of may so i'd encourage
you to take a look at those they contain demos as well um i will have a quick
overview of some of those features as well and um i think we'll have plenty of time left for questions and answers so
uh if there are topics that i haven't covered uh topics from previous webcasts that you might like to
revisit please feel free to ask me questions and i'll do my best to answer so with that
what i want to cover today briefly what amazon elastic transcoder is
why we think you should use elastic transcoder it's key features the new features that we recently launched and
go through some resources that are available to you these are mostly web links to documentation forums and so on and
then leave plenty of time for questions and answers in the new features section i will also
cover some demos of those new features so what is amazon elastic transcoder
well we designed elastic transcoder to uh do video transcoding in the cloud we
focused on uh file-based video transcoding so on-demand assets um and
we we really designed it with four main uh pillars in in mind the first is
that we designed elastic transcoder to be easy to use and that the the ease of use manifests
itself in really three ways the first is through a management console the aws management console which i'll be using
to drive the demo later on in the in the webcast so essentially that's a user interface that you can use to configure
and submit jobs to the transcoder service we have apis and sdk so we have a single
api and that's available through the popular aws sdks that you can download
so we have sdks available for most languages that people are using from
scripting languages like php and python to java and node.js etc
we also have predefined transcoding presets so what we've done is we've taken commonly uh requested
output formats like targeting an iphone or targeting a tablet or a 720p output
and we've wrapped those into transcoding presets that you can just call up from within uh the transcoder
service you can do that both from the management console as well as through the apis and that enables you to get
started quickly so if you just want to target something that will play back on most smartphones there's a preset that
will enable you to do that the second pillar is that we made elastic transcoders scalable so we
designed with scalability in mind and what that really means is that we've architected the system so that it
doesn't have any bottlenecks in terms of trying to try to scale the system up to cope with
large amounts of jobs and large quantities of video we also have a feature called
transcoding pipelines which i'll go into in a little bit more detail later on and those enable you to
perform parallel transcoding to actually have multiple transcoding jobs running at the same time
the third pillar for elastic transcoder is that it's cost effective like all aws services there were no minimums there
were no commitments and we have a very simple to understand pricing model which is per minute uh
output duration so if you think about the output that you're creating let's say you're transcoding a 10 minute video
we charge you for 10 minutes if you're transporting a 20 minute video we charge you for 20 minutes so it's very simple
to understand and perhaps more importantly it's very easy to predict what your cost will actually be because
it's just based on the duration of your output content and then finally we designed elastic
transcoder to be managed it's a fully managed service so what that means is that simula similar to our rds uh
database service we take the hassle the headaches out of actually managing the underlying engine
the underlying in this case the underlying transcoding engine so you don't have to worry about scaling it
you don't have to worry about um designing it for performance you don't have to worry about licensing the codex
that we actually use that's all part of the service and it's all baked into the service pricing
so why we think customers should use elastic transcoder and why customers are using elastic transcoder firstly they
don't need to manage volume so i think we can all agree that there's increasing amounts of content that's out there um
video is is the the fastest growing content type on the internet today and there's no signs that that will um that
that will decrease in the future so typically you would need to build a system to to scale
and that's what we've done with elastic transcoder you also don't need to worry about peaks
and buildings to manage peaks that tends to be uneconomical because you're typically going to have to build
a build out a system to cope with a transcoding a peak library of content
perhaps a backlog of content and you may never see that amount of content again or you may see it on an infrequent basis
so as a result anything that you've built out will not be running at optimal capacity and you'll just be wasting
money by doing that so because this is a fully managed service you don't need to worry about that that's that's our
problem that we manage for you and you know typically what we see amongst our customers when they use the service is
that they'll try it um give us a little bit of content to transcode then they will send us a large backlog of content
they might have a library of content that they've stored up that they want to make available through a website or a
mobile application or something like that and they'll transcode this large amount of content you know tens of
thousands hundreds of thousands millions of minutes even in some cases and
that will happen over a short period um and then they'll reduce
their transcoding volume to what we call a steady state now the steady state might depend on the kind of customer you
know it might be tens of thousands of minutes a day it might be hundreds of thousands of minutes a day it doesn't it really
depends on the customer but the point is that there was this peak amount of content to
start with and if they were building something themselves they would have needed to build to accommodate for that
peak and using the transcoder service elastic transcoder they don't need to do that
finally customers don't need to manage format support so we add support for
popular file formats codecs wrappers containers all the time
we recently added support for outputting to webm and the apple http live
streaming hls format and that's something that we do that customers don't need to worry about
supporting and maintaining so a few customer examples uh grammar
film is an independent film producer in the uk they like the fact that it's a very
simple to use service they were able to integrate into their workflow very easily and that it worked quickly for
them another example is elsevier the
publishing uh company they have a number of properties but one of them is a website called clinical key and it's a
website for clinicians for medical professionals a subscription website and it contains a large amount of
images but videos as well illustrating medical procedures and they can be short
or they could be long i mean they have videos of sleep studies and things like that up there so they had a large quantity of these
videos they needed to transcode and then an ongoing volume of content that they needed to transcode as well and uh the
application architect for elsevier was was pleased with the service um mostly because of the ease of
integration and the fact that it just ran reliably for them and that they they
were able to meet all their transcoding requirements using it then another customer example is a i'm
going to call this youtube for uh the life sciences benchfly is an online video platform for
life scientists so if you are a um an experimental life scientist and you know
you have a lab procedure that you want to show to your colleagues and other professionals in the field you can
use benchfly to actually do that and it's uh you can shoot the content on your on your phone on your mobile device
uh or on a camcorder and upload it to the platform and then they will enable that content to be shared to
other uh live scientists and um again they use the the elastic transcoder service
to transcode a backlog of content initially and then use it on an ongoing basis to transcode content that is
uploaded by their customers so what are the key features of elastic
transcoder i mentioned coding pipelines earlier so transcoding pipelines are in fact let me
flip over to my architecture diagram on the next slide because it'll make it easier to understand so what you see in
the middle uh the rounded rectangular box is the elastic
transcoder service itself there are a number of transcoding pipelines that are
in the uh in the transcoding service up to four per aws account
and the transcoding pipeline is essentially a transcoding job queue and you can see what the inside of that
pipeline looks like at the bottom of the screen so the transcoding pipeline contains the transcoding jobs and it
essentially connects your input amazon s3 bucket to an output f3 bucket and so
it will process jobs from the input bucket to the output bucket now the nice thing is that we give you
more than one transcoding pipeline so you can create different workflows using
um using that mechanism you can do multiple jobs in parallel
you could decide that okay i want one pipeline to be empty most of the time and i just want to use that for what i
consider to be high priority jobs so is there as a mechanism for you to give you flexibility in terms of your design
so transcoding pipelines enable you to organize your transcoding jobs and they also enable you to do parallel
transcoding translating presets which are indicated on my diagram as the
um uh the little rectangular box with a with a cut-off corner at the
bottom there are essentially uh templates of transcoding settings so
transcoding presets are where you would define your bit rate your resolution or
codec settings audio parameters and so on and we as i said earlier we we provide
you with predefined presets for popular output formats now you can use those predefined uh presets as a starting
point for your own custom presets and create your own custom presets which are then available across your aws account
we provide monitoring and management both via the aws management console as
well as via the api so through the api you can look at the pipe the pipeline
status you can look at the jobs that are executing you can pull all the information that you would get through the management
console and i'll show you some examples of that in a few minutes we have notifications so we use the uh
aws simple notification service or fns to which is a pub sub
model for providing notification messages so we will publish
messages to um an fns topic for different situations such as
processing completed warning or error and the idea there is that you can subscribe to those topics and they can
be the same topic or they could be different topics and you can then be notified when one of those events happen
uh happens now that's a much more efficient way of doing things than continuously polling an api to figure
out what's going on in terms of format support
um i'll start from the bottom rather weirdly maybe i should reorder the slide we we support common input formats what
does that mean well we support formats that you'll find on the web so those will be things like mp4 mov
mpeg2 flv files and so on we'll also support some camera files
such as xcam and will also support files that come from
dvds for instance like vobs so there's a large variety of input formats that we support
in terms of output formats when we launched we supported a single combination of codecs and
in an mp4 container so we can we supported h.264 video aac audio in an
mp4 container since we launched we've added um h.264 aac in an mpeg-2
transport stream and we've also added webm output that's vp8 video and vorbis audio now as you
can imagine one of the reasons for doing mpeg-2 transport output is so that we can support hls so we also now support
our hls segmented file sets we're available in multiple regions so
we're available in six of the aws regions uh and the idea there is really that it makes typically makes sense for
you to transcode your content um close to where your content is actually situated so if you have all your content
sitting in um us us west say northern california then it
probably makes sense for you to transcode that content in that same region and then finally we have console and api
support uh there's a single amazon sdk per language so when you download the
java sdk for instance it contains uh it is the sdk for all of the supported aws
services so a common faq is hey i'm using the java sdk and i can't
access a new feature well download the java sdk again and you should find that
new feature part of the sdk because when we ship a new feature in
the service the sdks will get revved
so let's go on to pricing how do we price the service we price per minute with no minimum
commitment that's per output minute standard definition is half the price of high definition so uh as an example in
the us east and u.s west oregon regions standard def is 1.5 u.s cents per minute
hd is 3 u.s cents per minute um hd we define is anything that is 720p or above
which is the common definition for web for web video at least and that is the output format so you
might have an hd input that's 1080p but if you're only outputting to 480p
then you're being charged sd rates we have a free tier of 20
standard definition or 10 high definition minutes per month and that's really designed to enable you to try the
service to try different presets to see if it works out for you and that's a
free tier that renews automatically every month so you get those three minutes every month
we also within reason will forgive you for failed jobs so you know if you have jobs that fail part way through
transcoding um and you know you would normally have been uh charged for um
however many minutes of transcoding we did on your behalf until the job failed we'll forgive you for that if those
failures become excessive then we'll probably contact you that will typically contact you in any case so we can try to
figure out what's going wrong we also don't have data charges within a region now this can be a big deal for
people um if you're if they're dealing with large input files and again there's another reason why it makes sense to use
the service um in the same region as where your input files are located so if
your files are if you're working with files in eu for instance then do the transcoding in eu because
you're not moving the files around and we're not charging you for those data transfer charges
so new elastic transcoder features visual watermarking is the first new
feature that we that we released uh two weeks ago visual watermarking lets you add a
a an image a static image to over your video output these are commonly referred to as in the us as
bugs and in some other parts of the world as dogs
digital online graphics and we will accept a jpeg or a portable
network graphics file that you specify and enable you to overlay that onto the
onto the video output we also enable you to specify a bit rate
cap parameter and i'll go into that in a little bit more detail but basically you can use this to
guarantee that the output bit rate never exceeds a certain value this can be very useful um in certain situations where
you're streaming um over a constrained type of channel uh or to a particular
type of device similarly we have a frame rate cap parameter so that you can specify that
the output frame rate never exceeds a certain value typically this is useful for supporting particular devices that
are just not capable of playing back um video that has a a frame rate above a
certain value i'll show you a demo of of those features
